title: Rear Wheel - Removal

body.body: Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall, causing injury to the operator or damage to the motorcycle.
Support the motorcycle so the rear wheel is raised clear of the ground.
Release the lock nuts on both the left hand and right hand chain adjuster bolts.
Remove the spindle nut and washer then support the wheel and withdraw the spindle. Discard the nut.
Lower the wheel to the ground, and noting its position, release the brake caliper and carrier from the lug on the swinging arm.
Do not allow the caliper to hang on the brake hose as this may damage the hose.
Damaged hoses could cause brake failure leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Roll the wheel forward until the drive chain can be detached from the rear sprocket.
Manoeuvre the wheel out of position and recover the spacers from the hub and drive flange.
Do not allow the wheel to rest on the brake disc as this may damage the disc leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
To prevent wheel and wheel bearing damage, ensure dirt and debris are not allowed to enter the wheel bearings.
